Dendritisk cell tar bitar ut av mikrober, far till närmaste lymfen, den letar en T-hjälpecell med rätt antikropp, den aktiveras (virgin) och börjar duplicerar, några blir i lymfen som T-minnesceller. Andra går och strider mot mikrob, andra går i mitten av lymfnoden och aktiverar B-lymfceller som duplicerar sig och börjar bilda antikroppar.

Fagocyter konsumerar och kommunicerar ytprotein till lymfocyter.

T-lymfocyter dödar infekterade celler

Fagocyter kan döda kroppets egna celler om de är infekterade av virus, bakterie, cancerceller
Infekterade celler slutar producera ett ytprotein som friska celler producerar och fagocyt gör mha enzym så att de tillför programerad celldöd

Värme och inflammation accelerarer cellmetabolism så de kan repareras snabbare

Lymfocytor från benmärg

För mycket för att handla-> signalerar hypotalamus för att höja temperatur

Antikroppr kan
neutralisera (omge virus så de kan inte gå in)
Markera
Klumpa virus
Singalerar andra fagocyter och lymfocyter

Babyn får i mamman antikroppar och från mammas mjölk

Skin och mucus membran

Cytokiner sprider signal

Hjälpr T cell aktiverar B celler. Hjälpar t safegusrd checkar

I've learned a bit about immunity in my physio class and I'm currently learning about it in my medical microbio class and had some quick questions.

So at 6:50, it seems to be saying that B cells can engulf and present antigens for Helper cells to detect in order to activate fully activate B cells to proliferate. But that way I learned it was that Helper T cells have to be activated first by binding to an APC (macrophage) that has an antigen bound to an MHCII receptor. Once the Helper T cell is activate, the Helper cell itself is the one that presents the antigen to a matching B cell. Once the Helper T cell with the specific antigen finds the right B cell, then it secrets ILs to activate the B cell to make plasma and memory cells. It seems logical to think that naive B cells with the correct B cell receptors can bind antigens themselves, but do they or can only memory B cells bind directly to the antigen?

Also, for how our immune cells to recognize self from nonself, I've learned that it is because each B/T cell before it gets fully release is basically screened and passed through auto-antigen presenting cells that present all possible self antigens, and any immune cell that are produced that can bind to self antigens are stimulated to undergo apoptosis. So from my understanding, the reason our immune system doesn't attack our own cells is that any immune cell that can potentially target our own cells are destroyed before it can be released. Can someone confirm this?

Also wished these episodes talked about interferons. Their mechanism of action is pretty cool.

Skin... Mucous membranes... Humoral immune response.... Long ago, the three immune system fail-safes lived together in harmony. Then everything changed when the bacteria, viruses, cancer and all pathogens attacked. Only a certain lymphocyte that forms in the thymus, master of all immune defences, could stop them. But when the world needed it most, it vanished. A hundred years passed and Richard Gershon and Kazunari Kondo discovered the new lymphocyte, named T-cell. And although its immune response skills are great, it still has a lot to learn before it's ready to save anyone. But I believe the T-cell can save the world.

I really want to express how thankful I am for Crash Course and all of their tremendous content. I went back to school this year for the first time since 2012. I started the year with some introductory math and biology courses before taking Microbiology and Anatomy & Physiology this Fall. For me, these two classes were quite demanding, but this entire series of videos truly helped and guided me through A&P. Hank's delivery, intelligence, and overall passion for what he's presenting really help the information stick with you long after you've watched these videos. It's seriously amazing; the LUXURY of having forty-seven 10min A&P presentations in your pocket (i.e. smartphone) wherever you go, 24/7, is incredible. Before going back to school this year, I was always one of those "I'll just learn what I need to for the test" students. And honestly, when I first started watching Crash Course, I didn't think that would change. But after doing very well this year (I never was a good student prior) I've come to love watching these videos so much that even though school is now done for me this year I'm STILL waking up every morning and going back through some of these videos out of habit and out of simply looking forward to learning. I actually care about learning now-it's rewarding and enjoyable. Doing well on tests turned into a by-product of my desire to spend time learning. I deeply appreciate the content that Crash Course offers to everyone. Hank, your voice was in my head for every A&P test this semester. And it worked :)

This comment goes for the entire team at Crash Course, of course. The graphics are stellar, the content is excellent, the whole channel is tremendous. Thank you.
